description: Inherited from Middle English stomakere, stomachere, perhaps after Anglo-Norman *estomachier. Equivalent to stomach +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A type of men's waistcoat. [15th–18th c.]

(now chiefly historical) An ornamental cloth, often embellished with embroidery or jewelry, worn over the chest by women beneath their bodices or by men and women as the central part of an open shirt, blouse, or jacket.
examples: Stomacher brooch of brilliants and fine oriental pearls.

entries.meaning: A similar item of mail worn over and protecting the stomach.
